verses.text: Paul, an apostle of Christ Jesus by the will of God, according to the promise of life that is in Christ Jesus,
verses.comment: Paul announces his apostleship as God's initiative, referencing the promise of eternal life in Christ. This sets a deeply Christ-centered foundation (see John 10:28), affirming Christ as the source of true life.

verses.text: To Timothy, my beloved child: grace, mercy, and peace from God the Father and Christ Jesus our Lord.
verses.comment: Paul uses affectionate paternal language for Timothy, showing an early example of spiritual fatherhood and succession (compare 1 Corinthians 4:15).

verses.text: I thank God, whom I serve with a clear conscience, as my forefathers did, as I remember you in my prayers night and day.
verses.comment: Paul connects his worship to that of the faithful before him, underlining continuity in worship between the Old and New Covenants.

verses.text: I long to see you, remembering your tears, that I may be filled with joy.
verses.comment: Paul desires reunion for mutual encouragement and joy, revealing the depth of Christian fellowship and emotional bond within the apostolic community.

verses.text: I recall the sincere faith that is in you, which lived first in your grandmother Lois and your mother Eunice, and now, I am convinced, lives in you also.
verses.comment: Faith is shown as something alive and transmitted through generations, suggesting the importance of family and tradition in passing on the faith.

verses.text: For this reason, I remind you to fan into flame the gift of God that is in you through the laying on of my hands.
verses.comment: Paul affirms the transmission of spiritual gifts and authority via the laying on of hands—a practice indicating apostolic succession and the continuing work of the Spirit.

verses.text: For God did not give us a spirit of fear, but of power and love and self-control.
verses.comment: The Holy Spirit equips believers for courage, charity, and discipline—virtues embodied by those faithfully serving in leadership.

verses.text: So do not be ashamed of the testimony about our Lord, nor of me his prisoner, but share in suffering for the gospel by the power of God.
verses.comment: Endurance in hardship is connected with a willingness to identify with Christ’s witnesses and to rely on God’s empowering grace.

verses.text: He has saved us and called us to a holy calling, not because of our works but because of his own purpose and grace, which he gave us in Christ Jesus before time began,
verses.comment: Salvation is God's initiative, given before time, emphasizing divine grace, predestination, and holiness as the heart of the Christian life.

verses.text: and which has now been revealed by the appearing of our Savior Christ Jesus, who abolished death and brought life and immortality to light through the gospel.
verses.comment: Christ’s incarnation and resurrection are shown as the fulfillment of God’s plan, overcoming death and revealing eternal life—see Isaiah 25:8 and 1 Corinthians 15:54.

verses.text: For this purpose, I was appointed a preacher, apostle, and teacher,
verses.comment: Paul highlights his threefold ministry: preaching, apostleship, and teaching—each with distinct but united purposes for building up God's people.

verses.text: which is why I suffer these things. But I am not ashamed, for I know whom I have believed, and I am convinced that he is able to guard what has been entrusted to me until that day.
verses.comment: Paul’s confidence in Christ’s faithfulness sustains him in suffering; 'that day' alludes to the ultimate return and judgment (see 2 Tim. 4:8).

verses.text: Hold to the pattern of sound words that you have heard from me, in the faith and love that are in Christ Jesus.
verses.comment: Paul urges Timothy to preserve apostolic teaching—an early model for guarding doctrinal truth passed on through authoritative tradition.

verses.text: By the Holy Spirit who dwells in us, guard the good deposit entrusted to you.
verses.comment: The 'good deposit' refers to sound doctrine and authority passed on—protected by the Spirit within the community of faith.

verses.text: You know that all who are in Asia turned away from me, among whom are Phygelus and Hermogenes.
verses.comment: Paul laments betrayal and loneliness, a reminder of the cost of leadership and fidelity to the gospel.

verses.text: May the Lord grant mercy to the household of Onesiphorus, for he often refreshed me and was not ashamed of my chains,
verses.comment: Here Paul asks for mercy upon Onesiphorus' household—potentially indicating prayer for someone not present (possibly deceased), suggesting an early precedent for intercessory prayer for the departed (see 2 Maccabees 12:44-46).

verses.text: but when he arrived in Rome, he searched for me eagerly and found me—
verses.comment: Onesiphorus' zealous search for Paul in prison demonstrates loyal Christian friendship and works of mercy toward the imprisoned.

verses.text: may the Lord grant him to find mercy from the Lord on that day! And you know very well all the service he rendered at Ephesus.
verses.comment: Paul’s prayer that Onesiphorus may obtain mercy 'on that day' (the day of the Lord) appears to refer to intercessions for the dead—hinting at the enduring unity of the faithful both living and departed.
